newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICA TRUCKING STRIKE BITES ACROSS ALL SECTORS.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICA TRUCKING STRIKE BITES ACROSS ALL SECTORS.

text.p: A national trucking strike by around 36,000 workers, which kicked off Wednesday morning, had spread to all sectors of the South African economy by the afternoon, employer spokesman Johan van der Walt said.

"The strike is widespread with some companies at a complete standstill while others are still running...it has affected sectors across-the-board," van der Walt, who is chairman of the Road Freight Association, said.

Truckers went on strike Wednesday morning after a last minute attempt by the Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (CCMA) -- set up in terms of the new Labour Relations Act -- to mediate a wage dispute between employers and unions failed on Tuesday night.
The CCMA is a vehicle for dispute resolution which provides statutory dispute resolution services.

A Transport and General Workers Union (TGWU) spokesman told Reuters workers originally demanded 14 to 18 percent across-the-board, but the union was seeking members' mandate on a 10 percent offer from employers.
The further meeting between the two sides is planned for late Wednesaday.
Workers went on strike at major venues throughout the country including Johannesburg, the Western Cape, Vanderbijlpark, Empangeni, Durban and Pretoria.
Sectors of the economy affected include banking, air freight, waste companies, livestock vehicles, and the ferrying of chemicals and fuels.
By Wednesday afternoon it was not yet clear whether there had been any trucker blockades on major highways.
This is the first time in fifty years that unions organised in the sector have resorted to industrial action.
